research_summary: The Seattle Seahawks' path to Super Bowl XLVIII was a masterclass in resilience and strategic dominance. After a stellar 13-3 regular season in 2013, securing the NFC West title and home-field advantage, the Seahawks faced a gauntlet of playoff contenders. Their journey began on January 11, 2014, with a hard-fought 23-15 victory over the New Orleans Saints in the Divisional Round, a game defined by Marshawn Lynch's powerful runs and a stifling defensive performance led by the 'Legion of Boom.' The NFC Championship game on January 19th against their arch-rivals, the San Francisco 49ers, was an instant classic, a brutal, back-and-forth affair culminating in a nail-biting 23-17 Seahawks victory sealed by Richard Sherman's game-winning pass deflection in the end zone. This win sent the Seahawks to their second Super Bowl in franchise history, setting the stage for a clash against Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos.
key_facts: The Seahawks finished the 2013 regular season with a 13-3 record, securing the NFC's #1 seed.
Seattle's defense, known as the 'Legion of Boom,' allowed the fewest points in the NFL in 2013 (231 points).
Marshawn Lynch rushed for 1,257 yards and 12 touchdowns in the 2013 regular season.
Russell Wilson threw for 26 touchdowns and 9 interceptions during the 2013 regular season.
